GOALSTATEMENT: Given a grade level reading passage Tyler will be able to answer 7 out of 10 comprehension questions correctly.

When given a writing prompt Sname will write a paragraph with a topic sentence including three supporting details and a concluding sentence with fewer than ___  mechanical errors in ___ out of ___ trials.
Tyler will increase number fluency by computing 100 basic facts (multiplication, division) in 5 minutes.
Tyler will demonstrate self advocacy skills to request help and clarification of directions 6 out of 10 times.
Tyler will write class assignments in student planner.
Tyler will take all needed materials to class.
Tyler will improve his speech skills to access the general classroom.

Tyler will  use appropriate eye contact, demonstrate nonverbal communication consistent with intent, demonstrate understanding of nonverbal cues by responding appropriately, use appropriate tone of voice, demonstrate appropriate personal space within structured therapy settings during the current IEP year.

Tyler will give sufficient information, give directions effectively, give polite suggestions, ask for information and/or assistance, explain a problem and/or steps to solve it in structured therapy settings during the current IEP year.
Given picture or text prompts Tyler will use words correctly in context during the current IEP year.
Given   modeling, a picture, or structured activities, Tyler will expand mean sentence length during the current IEP year.
Tyler will improve memory for following directions to access the general education curriculum by using strategies such as self-repetition, requests for repetition, visualizing, etc.
Tyler will increase keyboard typing to 20 words per minute.
Given an 7th  Grade Level Passage, Tyler will read 138 WPM

When given a writing prompt, Logan will improve his total words written, develop grade level sentence fluency and conventions as measured by writing assignments and progress monitoring.
Given 10  basic multiplication and division problems, Logan will correctly complete 8 out of 10.

By April 2011, with the support of the SLP, Logan will develop an understanding and application of what a 'healthy speaking voice' means by  conducting simple research and creating a 'vocal hygiene log' that includes the following activities: 1) Defining  what a 'healthy' voice sounds like 2) Describing behaviors that contribute to a healthy voice and an unhealthy voice 3) Identifying his personal healthy and unhealthy uses of his voice (loud volume & yelling), including the ability to define when to adjust volume 4) Completing monthly checks and evaluate his vocal habits, sucessess and on-going needs

During structured group language activities Logan will demonstrate the ability to maintain a topic of conversation by completing any of the following skills: - add a comment -ask a question -use a non-verbal 'filler' such as nodding head or saying "uh-huh" -using a verbal 'filler' such as "cool' or "I know" etc; He will use skills during structured activities to complete 2 or more conversational turns during a 1-3 minute interaction with a peer.
When given a 4th grade reading passage, Logan will increase his fluency to 100 word per minute and comprehension to 80% as measured by curriculum based measures and progress monitoring data.

Given a reading selection from a grade level content class textbook, Wyatt will determine the general topic of the selection by examining the illustrations and other text features within that selection prior to attempting to read the selection.

Sky will increase problem solving and complete challenging activities during individual choice and adult led activities.  We will know she has mastered this when she completes tasks with auditory or visual directions 3/4 opportunities as measured 1x a month through the IEP year.

Sky will increase her attention and focus on activities.  We will know Sky can do this when she remains focused on the activity for 7-10+ minutes with fading adult prompts as observed 1x a month through out the IEP year.

Sky will participate in small group and play activities to increase math concepts.  We will know she can do this when Sky can correctly count up to 10 objects using one to one correspondence and can verbally give the correct amount up to 5 in 3 /4 trials as observed 1x per month through the IEP year.

Sky will correctly produce /s/ blend words (stop, spin, skip, etc) with 70% accuracy during preschool activities as measured by informal data taken monthly by 2/1/13.
Sky will identify and label items/pictures during preschool activities in 7 out of 10 opportunities as measured by informal data taken monthly by 2/1/13.

Sky will retell simple 3-4 part stories using subjective pronouns (he, she, they) and present progressive verb tense ("is walking") during preschool activities in 7 out of 10 opportunities as measured by informal data taken monthly by 2/1/13.

Travis will increase communication skills by imitating and producing sounds of language in isolation and single words in 4 out of 5 opportunities in routine classroom activities as measured by twice monthly data collection

Travis will increase communication skills in the preschool setting by expressing  his needs and wants making choices, using pictures, or using word approximations 4 out of 5 trials as measured by twice monthly data collection.
Travis will point to an object or picture which is named by a teacher/therapist with 80% accuracy as measured by twice monthly data collection.

Travis will increase his attention span to 2-3 minutes or more on a small group or one-on-one teachers directed activity.  We will know Travis can do this when he follows instructions and physically engages in the teacher directed activity for 2-3 minutes or more, observed in 3 of 4 opportunities, measured two times a month by data collection and classroom observation.

Travis will increase his independence throughout classroom routine and in meeting personal needs. We will know he can do this when he puts away his own personal belongings at arrival time, when he gets his coat, puts it on, takes it off,and puts it away independently, and when he follows through the daily arrival time routine with 3 or fewer cues,  (i.e. making eye contact, hanging up or putting away his personal items, signing in, washing hands, and then becoming engaged in an arrival time activity) observed in more than 75% of opportunities, measured two times a month by data collection and classroom observation.

Travis will increase his pre-academic skills. We will know he can do this when he demonstrates knowledge of colors by pointing to or correctly labeling identified colors, when he points to or correctly labels identified basic shapes (circle, square, triangle, star), and when he can sort objects by one attribute (cars, color, shape, etc.), observed in 3 of 4 opportunities, measured two times a month by classroom observation and data collection.

Travis will use writing utensils to create a picture, utilizing a variety of controlled strokes (vertical, horizontal, circular). He will spend 5 or more minutes on the task, requiring a decreasing number of verbal cues, observed in 3 of 4 opportunities, measured two times a month by data collection and classroom observation.

Travis will increase his ability to follow directions. We will know he can do this when he follows one and two-step directions that are not routine related, observed in 3 of 4 opportunities, measured two times a month by classroom observation and data collection.

After reading a text selection in class, Devon will summarize with 2 - 3 sentences, written or orally, indicating the main idea from the selection.

Given an assignment to write a paragraph, story, or brief essay, Devon will develop a brief outline or other plan indicating the information, in as few words as possible, which is to be included in the final written paragraph in a logical or chronological sequence (e.g., formal outline, informal outline, simple list, web outline, power outline, diagram, simple series of pictures, etc.).

Ashley will increase in the use of cognitive strategies to build knowledge from text. Evidence of strategy use will be based on frequency, appropriateness and effectiveness of the use of strategies, and the complexity of texts to which strategies are applied. The strategies follow. 1. Activating background knowledge 2. Questioning 3. Searching for information 4. Summarizing 5. Integrating graphically - using mapping, outlining, etc. 6. Structuring the response 7. Elaborative Interrogation. Asking "why?" 8. Question-Answer-Relations Identifying the relationship between a text, a question related to that text, and the answer to the question. Possible relationships include: (a) explicit (answer is right there), (b) implicit (answer is inferred from a sentence or possibly two), and (c) combined information (answer required integration of text information from many locations, and integration with prior knowledge).
In order to be successfully employed, Ashley will utilize self advocacy skills to access the accommodations and modifications she wants and/or is entitled to.
